choices.text: Small cell carcinoma of the lung
Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with an incidentally discovered pulmonary nodule undergoes further evaluation to characterize the nodule. An imaging study that measures glucose metabolic activity is conducted to help determine the likelihood of malignancy. Which of the following will not be avid on FDG PET scan?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Typical carcinoid

 

Option A:

 

Typical carcinoid does not show avid uptake FDG PET as it is well-differentiated.

 

Typical carcinoids are generally well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors and tend to show less avidity on FDG PET scans compared to more aggressive forms of lung cancer because of their lower metabolic rate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Incorrect. Small cell carcinoma of the lung is a highly aggressive cancer that usually shows high metabolic activity on FDG PET scans.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Atypical carcinoids may show some uptake on FDG PET scans, reflecting a higher metabolic rate than typical carcinoids, although less than more aggressive tumors.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma is a high-grade neuroendocrine tumor that typically shows high FDG uptake on PET scans due to its aggressive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typical carcinoids often demonstrate low metabolic activity on FDG PET scans, making them less likely to be avid on such imaging, in contrast to other more aggressive types of neuroendocrine tumors like small cell carcinoma and large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 916

questions.text: In the interpretation of PET-CT scans, which organ's normal physiological function can often be mistaken for pathological uptake, potentially leading to a false-positive result in the evaluation of a patient with suspected malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Urinary bladder

 

Option C:

 

The urinary bladder is a common site for false positives on PET-CT scans because it is a collection site for FDG excreted from the kidneys, which can be mistaken for pathological uptake.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. The testes may show physiological uptake due to their metabolic activity but are less commonly a site of false-positive due to the expected lower metabolic rate compared to pathological processes.

 

Option B. Incorrect. The pancreas can show variable FDG uptake in normal physiological conditions, yet it is less likely to be mistaken for a false-positive as it usually has a uniform distribution pattern that can be distinguished from focal lesions.

 

Option D. Incorrect. While lymph nodes can show increased uptake due to inflammation or infection (reactive hyperplasia), it is less common for them to present as a false positive compared to the urinary bladder where excreted FDG accumulates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The urinary bladder is a common site for false positives due to the excretion and accumulation of FDG in PET Scan.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 916

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes presents to the emergency department with chest pain that began approximately 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as a pressure-like sensation in the center of his chest that radiates to his left arm. He also reports shortness of breath and nausea. On physical exam, his blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg, heart rate is 100 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. The ECG shows ST-segment depression in leads II, III, and aVF. Troponin levels are elevated. What test can detect areas of reversible myocardial ischemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thallium scan

 

Option C:

 

Thallium scan is a useful diagnostic tool in detecting reversible myocardial ischemia. This is performed both at rest and during exercise.

 

Thallium scan is a type of nuclear imaging test that can show areas of myocardial ischemia and distinguish between reversible and irreversible ischemic damage using exercise and rest imaging techniques.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A. Coronary angiography. Incorrect: It is an invasive test primarily used to define coronary anatomy and is not used to directly assess myocardial viability.

 

Option B. MUGA Scan. Incorrect: It is used to assess the pumping function of the ventricles but does not provide specific information on myocardial ischemia or infarction.

 

Option D. Resting echocardiography. Incorrect: It can show wall motion abnormalities that suggest ischemia but may not differentiate between reversible and irreversible myocardial damage without the use of stress modalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thallium scan is used in diagnosing reversible myocardial ischemia. The scan involves imaging both at rest and during exercise or pharmacologic stress to visualize areas with reduced blood flow that may return to normal on rest imaging, indicating reversibility and the potential benefit from revascularization.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 232

choices.text: It uses gamma emitting radioisotope
It is used for 2D image reproduction
Lead collimators are used
It provides functional and anatomical information

questions.text: In evaluating a patient with suspected malignancy, a physician explains the role of advanced imaging techniques. Which statement correctly describes the capabilities of a Positron Emission Tomography (PET) scan in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It provides functional and anatomical information

 

Option D:

 

PET scans provide functional information based on metabolic activity with the use of radioisotopes like 18-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG), and when fused with CT or MRI, they can also provide detailed anatomical information.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A. Incorrect. While gamma rays are a byproduct of the annihilation event when positrons interact with electrons, PET scans use positron-emitting isotopes.

 

Option B. Incorrect. PET scans provide three-dimensional images, not merely two-dimensional reproductions.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Lead collimators are not used in PET imaging; they are associated with SPECT scanning, which relies on gamma rays emitted directly by the radioisotope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PET scans utilize positron-emitting radioisotopes to detect areas of high metabolic activity often associated with cancer cells. These functional images can be combined with anatomical imaging modalities like CT or MRI to pinpoint the location of the metabolic abnormalities, aiding in the diagnosis, staging, and monitoring of treatment response in malignancies.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 916

choices.text: It captures a single photon emission with an energy peak at 511 keV
It detects two photons emitted simultaneously, each with an energy peak at 511 keV
It utilizes a single photon emission with an energy peak at 211 keV
It relies on dual photon emissions, each with an energy peak at 211 keV

questions.text: While discussing various imaging modalities with a group of medical students, a radiologist details the underpinnings of positron emission tomography (PET). What is the fundamental principle behind a PET scan that allows for its imaging capability?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It detects two photons emitted simultaneously, each with an energy peak at 511 keV

 

Option B:

 

PET scans operate on the principle of detecting two gamma photons that are emitted in opposite directions, each with an energy peak of 511 keV, after a positron from the radiotracer interacts with an electron resulting in annihilation.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A. Incorrect. PET scan imaging is based on the detection of two photons, not a single photon.

 

Option C. Incorrect. The energy peak for photons detected in a PET scan is 511 keV, not 211 keV.

 

Option D. Incorrect. While PET scans do involve dual photon emissions, they occur at an energy peak of 511 keV, not 211 keV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A PET scan traces the path of positron-emitting radionuclides in the body. Upon encountering electrons, positrons undergo annihilation, resulting in the emission of two gamma photons of 511 keV, moving in approximately opposite directions. The simultaneous detection of these two photons allows for the precise localization of the positron annihilation event, enabling three-dimensional imaging of metabolic processes in the body.

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 916

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with a history of lung nodules is undergoing evaluation to differentiate between benign and malignant processes. The oncologist orders an imaging study that utilizes a compound known for its uptake in high metabolic activity tissues. Which of the following compounds are used in PET scan?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluorodeoxyglucose

 

Option A:

 

Fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) is a radioactive tracer used in positron emission tomography (PET) scanning. FDG is a glucose analog that is taken up by cells with high metabolic activity, such as cancer cells, making it useful for imaging tumors.

 

Explanations:

 

Option B. Incorrect. Technetium pertechnetate is not typically used in PET scanning; it is used in other types of nuclear medicine scans, such as thyroid scans.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Thallous chloride is used in myocardial perfusion imaging and not routinely in PET scanning for oncologic evaluation.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Gallium citrate is used in nuclear medicine imaging to detect inflammation and certain types of cancer, but it is not the compound typically used in PET scanning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) is the compound commonly used in PET scans to evaluate metabolic activity in various tissues. This radioactive tracer is utilized primarily to detect areas of increased glucose metabolism, which is a characteristic of malignancies, thus helping in the diagnosis, staging, and monitoring response to therapy in cancer patients.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 916

choices.text: Tc HMPAO SPECT

questions.text: An 84-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease requires imaging to evaluate cerebral perfusion. Which imaging modality is best suited for assessing regional cerebral blood flow in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tc HMPAO SPECT

 

Option A:

 

Tc HMPAO SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) uses the radiotracer technetium-99m hexamethylpropyleneamine oxime (HMPAO) to image cerebral perfusion, which is useful in the evaluation of various cognitive disorders, including Alzheimer's disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Incorrect. In-111 DTPA is used in cisternography and occasionally in infection imaging but is not typically used for cerebral perfusion imaging.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Tc-99m MIBI (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) is primarily used for myocardial perfusion imaging in cardiology, not for cerebral perfusion.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Thallium-201 scintigraphy is also used in myocardial perfusion imaging, as well as for certain types of oncological imaging, but not for cerebral perfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tc HMPAO SPECT is the preferred modality for imaging cerebral blood flow in this clinical context, aiding in the diagnosis and evaluation of Alzheimer's disease severity and progression.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 781

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman was diagnosed with breast cancer three years ago. She underwent a lumpectomy followed by chemotherapy and radiation therapy. She was then started on hormone therapy for five years. Her initial tumor was estrogen receptor-positive, progesterone receptor-positive, and HER2-negative. During her recent follow-up appointment, she complained of increasing bone pain in her right hip and lower back. The oncologist orders a bone scan to assess for bony metastases. The radioactive isotope of which of the following is used?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Technetium-MDP

 

Option B:

 

Technetium-MDP (methylene diphosphonate) is commonly used in bone scintigraphy to identify areas of bone remodeling or metastases due to its uptake in osteoblastic activity, making it the agent of choice for this patient's evaluation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. Technetium-pertechnetate is utilized primarily for thyroid and salivary gland imaging due to its affinity for thyroid tissue and salivary glands.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Technetium-DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used for renal cortical imaging and does not have a primary role in detecting bone metastases.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Technetium-MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) is used for dynamic renal scintigraphy to assess renal function and drainage, not for bone imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Technetium-MDP is the preferred radiotracer due to its high uptake in areas of osteoblastic activity associated with bone metastases.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 529

questions.text: A 48-year-old female with a history of renal transplantation 4 months prior is being evaluated for renal function. Which imaging modality should be utilized for functional assessment of her transplanted kidney?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tc 99m MAG3

 

Option D:

 

Tc 99m MAG3 is ideal for renal function evaluation in transplant recipients because it provides information on both glomerular filtration and tubular excretion

 

Explanations:

 

Option A. Incorrect. Tc 99m DMSA primarily assesses the renal cortex and is used for evaluating renal scarring and pyelonephritis, not routinely for post-transplant function.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Tc 99m DTPA measures the glomerular filtration rate but does not provide information on tubular function, which is significant in the evaluation of a transplanted kidney.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Captopril DTPA is used for the detection of renovascular hypertension, not routine post-transplant renal function assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate nuclear medicine imaging test to assess renal function in a patient who has undergone renal transplantation is Tc 99m MAG3 scan because it measures renal perfusion, function, and urinary excretion effectively in the post-transplant setting.

 

Ref: Grainger &; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 425

choices.text: A patient with inflammatory bowel disease, a patient with a positive fecal occult blood test, and a patient with splenosis post-trauma
A patient with inflammatory bowel disease, a patient with a positive fecal occult blood test, and a patient with a solitary pulmonary nodule
A patient with congestive cardiac failure, a patient with splenosis post-trauma, and a patient with a solitary pulmonary nodule
A patient with congestive cardiac failure, a patient with a positive fecal occult blood test, and a patient with splenosis post-trauma

questions.text: Which group of patients would benefit from a Technetium-99m labeled red blood cell (RBC) scan?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A patient with congestive cardiac failure, a patient with a positive fecal occult blood test, and a patient with splenosis post-trauma

 

Option D:

 

A Tc-99m labeled RBC scan is useful for detecting an occult GI bleed and splenosis. It is also used for a MUGA scan to evaluate cardiac function in patients with congestive cardiac failure.

 

A Tc-99m labeled RBC scan is useful for detecting an occult GI bleed and splenosis. It is also used for a MUGA scan to evaluate cardiac function in patients with congestive cardiac failure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. While a patient with a positive fecal occult blood test and a patient with splenosis would benefit from a Tc-99m labeled RBC scan, a patient with inflammatory bowel disease typically requires a labeled leukocyte scan to identify areas of inflammation.

 

Option B. Incorrect. A patient with inflammatory bowel disease requires a labeled leukocyte scan, and a patient with a solitary pulmonary nodule would need a PET scan rather than a labeled RBC scan.

 

Option C. Incorrect. A patient with congestive cardiac failure would benefit from a MUGA scan, a specific application of Tc-99m labeled RBC scan for cardiac function assessment. However, a solitary pulmonary nodule typically requires a PET scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Technetium-99m labeled red blood cell scans can be used for identifying occult gastrointestinal bleeding, evaluating cardiac function, and detecting ectopic splenic tissue after trauma.

 

Ref: Grainger &; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

choices.text: To look for renal scarring in a child with vesicoureteral reflux
To evaluate a patient with a duplex renal collecting system
To assess renal perfusion in a man with renal artery stenosis
To confirm the presence of an ectopic kidney in a patient

questions.text: In which of the following clinical situations is a Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) renal scan contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. To assess renal perfusion in a man with renal artery stenosis

 

Option C:

 

A DMSA scan is static and does not assess renal perfusion, which is necessary for evaluating the functional impact of renal artery stenosis. Dynamic renal scans like Tc-99m MAG3 or DTPA are used for this purpose.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. A Tc-99m DMSA scan is appropriate for evaluating renal cortical scarring in children with a history of vesicoureteral reflux as it provides detailed anatomical information of the renal cortex.

 

Option B. Incorrect. A DMSA scan is useful for investigating patients with duplex renal collecting systems by providing clear images of renal morphology.

 

Option D. Incorrect. A DMSA scan can help confirm the presence of an ectopic kidney due to its ability to provide detailed cortical imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DMSA scans are used to assess renal cortical structure and function, which is useful for diagnosing scarring, pyelonephritis, and anatomical abnormalities. They are not indicated for evaluating renal perfusion, which requires dynamic imaging such as Tc-99m MAG3 or DTPA scans.

 

Ref: Grainger &; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 446

choices.text: Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan
Computed tomography (CT) scan

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with rectal bleeding for the past 12 hours. He has a history of intermittent abdominal pain over the past few months, which was initially thought to be due to gastroenteritis. Ultrasound of the abdomen is inconclusive, and the pediatric surgeon suspects a Meckel's diverticulum. Which of the following investigations is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan

 

Option C:

 

Investigation of choice for Meckel’s diverticulum: Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan

 

The Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan, also known as a Meckel's scan, is particularly useful for identifying ectopic gastric mucosa within a Meckel's diverticulum, which may absorb the isotope and allow for visualization.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy typically, does not visualize a Meckel's diverticulum, as it is located in the ileum, beyond the reach of standard endoscopes.

 

Option B. Incorrect. MRI can offer detailed soft-tissue contrast but is not specific for identifying ectopic gastric tissue within a Meckel's diverticulum and may not conclusively diagnose the condition in this clinical context.

 

Option D. Incorrect. CT scans while useful for detailed cross-sectional imaging of the abdomen, are not as sensitive as a Meckel's scan for detecting ectopic gastric mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan is the investigation of choice for diagnosing Meckel's diverticulum, especially when presenting with painless rectal bleeding suggestive of ectopic gastric tissue.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 412

choices.text: Diffusely increased uptake
Diffusely decreased uptake

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of bone pain in his lower back, ribs, and hips. He also reports fatigue, weakness, and unintentional weight loss. On physical examination, he has diffuse tenderness to palpation in the areas of reported bone pain. Laboratory studies reveal anemia, hypercalcemia, and elevated serum protein levels. A plain X-ray of her femur reveals the following. A bone scan in this patient would likely show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cold spots

 

Option B:

 

"Cold spots" on a bone scan indicate areas of decreased bone metabolism, which can occur in conditions such as multiple myeloma, where the osteolytic activity outpaces osteoblastic repair, leading to areas of decreased uptake of the radiotracer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. "Hot spots" on a bone scan typically represent areas of increased osteoblastic activity and bone metabolism, often seen in conditions like osteomyelitis, healing fractures, or metastatic bone disease.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Diffusely increased uptake could suggest a systemic process affecting the bone metabolism, such as metabolic bone disease, but it is not typical for multiple myeloma, which usually presents with focal lytic lesions.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Diffusely decreased uptake is not characteristic of any particular pathology and could be seen in a technically inadequate study or severe generalized bone disease, which is less common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

“Cold spots" on a bone scan typically correlate with areas of decreased osteoblastic activity, which is consistent with the osteolytic lesions of multiple myeloma.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 527

choices.text: C11 methionine PET
Gallium 68 DOTATOC PET
99mTc pertechnetate scan

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented with recurrent headaches, palpitations, and sweating. Her blood pressure was found to be 170/110 mm Hg. Further testing revealed elevated urinary metanephrines. An MRI was negative. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Gallium 68 DOTATOC PET

 

Option C:

 

The clinical scenario suggests the possibility of a pheochromocytoma. Elevated urinary metanephrines further support this suspicion. An MRI, although sensitive, can sometimes miss smaller tumors. The next best step in management would be to perform functional imaging with a radiotracer that can specifically detect pheochromocytomas.

 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by gallium-68 somatostatin receptor DOTATOC PET scan.

 

This investigation is useful in the diagnosis of several neuroendocrine tumors. The compounds often used in molecular imaging with PET include 68Ga-DOTATOC, 68Ga-DOTATATE, and 68Ga-DOTANOC. They have a varying affinity to different somatostatin receptors.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: C11 methionine PET is used for brain tumors.

 

Option B: 18F-NaF PET is used for imaging bone pathology.

 

Option D: 99m Tc pertechnetate is useful in the case of thyroid nodules, ectopic gastric mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is important to recognize the role of Gallium 68 DOTATOC PET in localizing neuroendocrine tumors like pheochromocytomas when anatomical imaging such as MRI fails to detect the tumor. This PET scan identifies tumors based on their somatostatin receptor expression.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 890

choices.text: Endemic iodine deficiency
HCG induced thyrotoxicosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with palpitations, weight loss, and heat intolerance. Physical examination reveals a slightly enlarged thyroid gland, tachycardia, and fine tremors in the hands. Laboratory tests show a low thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level and elevated free thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3) levels. Radioactive iodine uptake scan of the patient showed the following result. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Graves' disease

 

Option A:

 

The given image shows diffusely increased uptake homogeneously suggestive of Graves’ disease.

 

Schematic showing thyroid scan appearance in various conditions:

 

 

Graves' Disease: An autoimmune disorder characterized by the overproduction of thyroid hormones (thyrotoxicosis), often with a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. The radioactive iodine uptake is typically high and homogeneous across the gland.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Endemic Iodine Deficiency: Typically presents with hypothyroidism, not thyrotoxicosis, and can lead to goiter. The radioactive iodine uptake may be variable, but typically low in areas of iodine deficiency.

 

Option C. Subacute Thyroiditis: An inflammatory condition of the thyroid that often follows an upper respiratory infection and can cause transient thyrotoxicosis. Radioactive iodine uptake is generally low due to damaged thyroid cells.

 

Option D. HCG Induced Thyrotoxicosis: Hyperemesis gravidarum or gestational trophoblastic disease can lead to elevated human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) levels, which can stimulate the thyroid. The thyroid is not typically enlarged, and radioactive iodine uptake can be normal or slightly elevated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radioactive iodine uptake is typically high and homogeneous across the thyroid gland in Grave’s disease.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 880

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a history of kidney stones, fatigue, and bone pain. Her serum calcium is elevated, and her parathyroid hormone level is also above the normal range. She has no significant family history of endocrine disorders. A diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism is considered. Which of the following is the most appropriate imaging study to localize the abnormal parathyroid tissue?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sestamibi scan

 

Option B:

 

A sestamibi parathyroid scan is a nuclear medicine test that uses a radioactive compound (sestamibi) which is absorbed by overactive parathyroid tissue. It is considered the best non-invasive way to localize parathyroid adenomas preoperatively due to its high sensitivity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CECT Neck: It can show the anatomy and possible pathologies of the parathyroid glands but is less sensitive for detecting small or ectopic parathyroid adenomas.

 

Option C. Radioiodine Scan: This scan is primarily used to assess thyroid function and diagnose thyroid cancer. It involves the use of radioactive iodine, which the thyroid gland absorbs but the parathyroid does not, thus it is not useful for evaluating parathyroid abnormalities.

 

Option D. Ultrasound Neck: Ultrasound is a first-line, non-invasive, and readily available imaging tool for examining the neck. It can identify abnormal parathyroid glands but is operator-dependent and less sensitive for detecting small or ectopic glands compared to sestamibi scans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best investigation to delineate parathyroid abnormalities is a sestamibi scan. Sestamibi is a radiotracer that is taken up by hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue, making it an excellent tool for identifying parathyroid adenomas or hyperplasia.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 595

choices.text: Sulfur colloid scan
Technetium pertechnetate scan

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse presents with abdominal pain and fever. His liver function tests are abnormal, and there is a concern for hepatic abscess. To evaluate the function of phagocytic cells in the liver and confirm the diagnosis, which of the following radiopharmaceuticals would be most appropriate for the imaging study?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sulfur colloid scan

 

Option A:

 

  • The correct answer is A, sulfur colloid scan. Sulfur colloid is a radiopharmaceutical used in nuclear medicine for imaging of phagocytic cells, such as monocytes and macrophages. This type of scan is commonly used to detect infection or inflammation in various parts of the body, such as the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and lymph nodes.
  • A. Sulfur Colloid Scan: Technetium-99m sulfur colloid is used for scanning the reticuloendothelial system, which includes phagocytic cells in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow. It's particularly useful in identifying focal nodular hyperplasia due to the uptake by Kupffer cells.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Thallium 201: This is a radiopharmaceutical used primarily in myocardial perfusion imaging. It mimics potassium and is taken up by viable myocardial cells, and is not used for imaging phagocytes.

 

Option C. Technetium Pertechnetate Scan: This scan is used primarily for imaging the thyroid gland and for Meckel's diverticulum because these tissues trap but do not organify the technetium. It is not used for phagocyte imaging.

 

Option D. MDP Scan: Methylene diphosphonate (MDP) is tagged with Technetium-99m for bone scanning. It is taken up by osteoblasts and shows areas of increased bone turnover. It's not used for imaging phagocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of suspected hepatic abscess, a sulfur colloid scan is useful due to its uptake by phagocytic cells, especially the Kupffer cells in the liver. This can help to differentiate between various hepatic lesions based on their phagocytic activity.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 876

questions.text: During a lecture on nuclear medicine, a medical student asks the radiologist about the terminology used to describe nuclides with the same number of neutrons but differing in the number of protons. Which of the following terms correctly describes these nuclides?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isotones

 

Option C:

 

Isotones: Nuclides with the same number of neutrons but different numbers of protons. These do not necessarily have the same atomic or mass numbers. An example would be Carbon-14 (6 protons, 8 neutrons) and Nitrogen-15 (7 protons, 8 neutrons).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Isotopes: Atoms that have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons. They have the same atomic number but different mass numbers. Examples include Carbon-12 and Carbon-14, both of which have 6 protons but differ in their number of neutrons.

 

Option B. Isobars: Atoms that have the same mass number, meaning the sum of protons and neutrons is the same, but they have a different number of protons (and thus different atomic numbers). An example is Carbon-14 and Nitrogen-14.

 

Option D. Isomers: Nuclides with the same number of protons and neutrons, hence the same atomic and mass numbers, but they are in different energy states due to different arrangements of the nucleons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isotones are a group of nuclides having the same neutron number but different proton numbers, which results in different elements with distinct properties. This knowledge is crucial for understanding the behavior of radioactive substances used in diagnostic imaging and therapy.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. His blood pressure is normal, and physical examination is unremarkable. His mother reports that he had a febrile urinary tract infection six months ago. Renal ultrasonography showed no hydronephrosis or stones, but the pediatrician is concerned about renal cortical damage. Which of the following imaging studies is most appropriate for evaluating the child for renal cortical scarring?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. DMSA

 

Explanation:

 

Renal cortical scarring is commonly caused by vesicoureteric reflux (VUR), which is a major risk factor for recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) in children. The most appropriate investigation to detect renal cortical scarring is a DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic Acid) scan, which is a static nuclear medicine scan used to assess the morphology of the kidneys.

 

Key points about DMSA scan:

 

  • Detects cortical defects and scarring due to recurrent infections.
  • Provides a static image of the kidney to identify areas of reduced uptake, indicating scarred or non-functioning renal tissue.
  • Technetium-99m is used as the tracer in the scan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. USG (Ultrasonography): Ultrasonography is the first-line investigation to assess structural abnormalities and hydronephrosis but is not sensitive for detecting renal scarring.

 

Option C. MCU (Micturating Cystourethrography): MCU is the investigation of choice for detecting vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) but does not provide information about cortical scarring. It is used to visualize reflux of urine from the bladder into the ureters during micturition.

 

Option D. DTPA (Diethylenetriamine Pentaacetic Acid) scan: DTPA is a functional nuclear scan used to assess glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal function and detect obstruction. It is not used for detecting cortical scars, as it shows overall function rather than morphology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For children with recurrent UTIs, the investigation sequence is as follows:

 

  1. USG: First-line to detect structural abnormalities and hydronephrosis.
  2. MCU: To detect vesicoureteric reflux (VUR).
  3. DMSA: To detect renal cortical scarring. DMSA provides a morphological, static image of the kidneys to identify areas of scarring, making it the investigation of choice for cortical damage.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of chronic kidney disease is referred for an evaluation of her renal function. To accurately assess her glomerular filtration rate (GFR), which of the following radioisotopes should be utilized?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DTPA

 

Option B:

 

DTPA (Diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid) is a radiotracer used in nuclear medicine renal imaging to measure GFR. It is freely filterable at the glomerulus without being reabsorbed or secreted by the renal tubules.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. OIH (Orthoiodohippurate) is primarily used in renal plasma flow measurement, not GFR.

 

Option C. Incorrect. DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used for renal cortical imaging to assess the renal cortex's structural and functional integrity but not for GFR measurement.

 

Option D. Incorrect. MAG 3 (Mercaptoacetyltriglycine) is used for renal imaging and provides information similar to OIH related to renal plasma flow, not specifically GFR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DTPA is the radiotracer of choice for measuring glomerular filtration rate (GFR) in patients with suspected or known renal impairment. It is crucial for assessing renal function due to its property of being freely filterable at the glomerulus without tubular secretion or reabsorption. This allows for precise calculation of the GFR, which is a critical indicator of kidney health.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 446

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of neuroendocrine tumor is being considered for targeted radiotherapy after showing progression on first-line therapy. Which of the following radioisotopes is used in the treatment of neuroendocrine tumors through peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lutetium 177 dotatate

 

Option B:

 

Lutetium-177 dotatate is a radioisotope used in PRRT for treating neuroendocrine tumors. It binds to somatostatin receptors on the tumor cells and delivers targeted radiation, thus treating the tumor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. Gallium-68 dotatate is used in PET-CT imaging for the localization of neuroendocrine tumors due to their expression of somatostatin receptors, but it is not used for treatment purposes.

 

Option C. Incorrect. SRS, or stereotactic radiosurgery is a form of radiation therapy that precisely delivers high-dose radiation to a target (such as a tumor) in the brain or spine, but is not the radioisotope itself used for treating neuroendocrine tumors.

 

Option D. Incorrect. An octreotide scan is a diagnostic nuclear medicine test used to detect tumors that have somatostatin receptors, such as neuroendocrine tumors. It is not a treatment but rather a diagnostic imaging procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lutetium-177 dotatate is the radioisotope used in PRRT for the treatment of neuroendocrine tumors. This therapy utilizes the tumor's somatostatin receptors to deliver targeted radiation, offering an effective treatment for patients with advanced neuroendocrine tumors

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 916

choices.text: SPECT gives better contrast and resolution compared to PET
PET is cost effective compared to SPECT
SPECT uses gamma emitting radioisotopes
The emissions of PET scan are charged particles

questions.text: Comment whether the following statements are false regarding PET and SPECT scans except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. SPECT uses gamma emitting radioisotopes

 

Explanation:

 

Single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) and Positron emission tomography (PET) are nuclear medicine imaging techniques that provide information about metabolic and functional processes in the body, which is not available through CT and MRI scans.

 

Compared to SPECT, PET is a more expensive technique that uses a positron-emitting radioisotope tracer, such as 18 F-FDG. However, PET provides better contrast and spatial resolution.

 

On the other hand, SPECT is a lower-cost technique that uses gamma-emitting radioisotope tracers like Technetium-99m, Iodine-123, and Iodine-131.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 916

choices.text: NaF PET scan

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer treated two years ago is evaluated for new-onset lower back pain. Her pain is persistent, worsens with movement, and is not relieved by over-the-counter pain medications. She denies any recent trauma or lifting heavy objects. A comprehensive metabolic panel is normal, but the alkaline phosphatase level is elevated. To assess for possible skeletal metastases, which imaging modality should be utilized first for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. NaF PET scan

 

Option A:

 

Sodium fluoride (NaF) PET scanning has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting bone metastasis, particularly osteolytic lesions, and is considered superior to traditional bone scintigraphy, especially in breast cancer patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. MRI - Incorrect for the first choice. While MRI can provide detailed images of bone and soft tissue, it is not typically the first-line imaging modality for detecting widespread bone metastases.

 

Option C. Bone scan - Incorrect. A traditional bone scan can detect metastatic disease but has lower sensitivity and specificity compared to NaF PET scan for osteolytic lesions.

 

Option D. PET-CT - Incorrect. PET-CT using 18F-FDG can detect metabolically active tumors but is less sensitive than NaF PET scan for purely osteolytic metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium fluoride (NaF) PET scanning is highly sensitive and specific for skeletal metastases and should be considered when there is a high clinical suspicion of metastatic disease.

 

Sensitivity and specificity of imaging modalities in bone metastasis:

 

18F NaF PET > FDG-PET > MRI > Bone scan

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No  916

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain that began several hours ago while he was mowing the lawn. The pain is described as a heavy sensation over his chest, radiating to his left arm. An ECG shows ST-elevation in the anterior leads. The emergency physician initiates standard treatment for acute myocardial infarction and plans further diagnostic evaluation to assess the area of infarction. Which of the following imaging agents is most appropriate for identifying myocardial damage in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tc-99m pyrophosphate

 

Option C:

 

Tc-99m pyrophosphate - Correct. Technetium-99m pyrophosphate is a radiopharmaceutical used in nuclear medicine imaging to detect areas of myocardial necrosis in an acute infarction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Thallium-201 - Incorrect. Thallium-201 is a radioactive tracer used in nuclear medicine cardiac stress tests to assess myocardial perfusion. It is not typically used to identify the area of infarction.

 

Option B. Gallium - Incorrect. Gallium is used for tumor imaging and infection localization, not for assessing myocardial infarction.

 

Option D. Cobalt-57 - Incorrect. Cobalt-57 is not typically used to assess myocardial infarction. It can be used in some diagnostic tests as a marker, but not in the context of acute myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Technetium-99m is specifically useful in identifying areas of myocardial necrosis due to its uptake in damaged cardiac muscle tissue.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition
